description: From Middle English penon, penoun, pynoun, Old French penon, French pennon, from  Latin penna (“feather”). See pen (“a feather”), and compare pennon, pinion.

definitionGroups.group: A flag normally used by naval vessels to represent a special condition.

entries.meaning: The broad pennant flown by commodores.
The church pennant indicating religious services are taking place aboard ship.
The commissioning pennant flown on ceremonial occasions.
(sports) The winning of a competition, represented by a flag.
examples: The New York Yankees have won the American League pennant far more often than any other team.

entries.meaning: A commemorative flag, traditionally triangular and made of felt, typically used to show support for a particular athletic team.
A rope or strap to which a purchase is hooked.
A sandstone between coal measures in parts of South Wales
Either of two species of libellulid dragonfly of the genus Macrodiplax, of the tropics and subtropics.
